front.title: Deployment Considerations for In-situ OAM with IPv6 Options

postal.street: Cessna Business Park, Sarjapura Marathalli Outer Ring Road

abstract.t: In-situ Operations, Administration, and Maintenance (IOAM) records operational and telemetry information in the packet while the packet traverses a path between two points in the network. This document outlines how IOAM can be enabled in a network.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: In-situ Operations, Administration, and Maintenance (IOAM) records operational and telemetry information in the packet while the packet traverses a path between two points in the network. defines how IOAM data fields are encapsulated in the IPv6 . This document discusses deployment options for networks which leverage IOAM data fields encapsulated in the IPv6 protocol.
Deployment considerations differ, whether the IOAM domain starts and ends on hosts or whether the IOAM encapsulating and decapsulating nodes are network devices that forward traffic, such as routers.

section.title: Considerations for IOAM deployment in IPv6 networks
section.t:
IOAM deployment in an IPv6 network should take the following considerations and requirements into account: It is desireable that the addition of IOAM data fields neither changes the way routers forward the packets, nor the forwarding decision the routers takes. The packet with the added OAM information should follow the same path within the domain that the same packet without the OAM information would follow within the domain even in the presence of ECMP. Such a behavior is particularly interesting for deployments where IOAM data fields are only added "on-demand", e.g. to provide futher insights in case of undesired network behavior for certain flows. Implementations of IOAM should ensure that ECMP behavior for packets with and without IOAM data fields is the same.
Given that IOAM data fields increase the total size of the packet, the packet size could exceed the PMTU. In particular, the incremental trace IOAM HbH Option, which is proposed to support hardware implementations of IOAM, changes Option Data Length en-route. Operators of an IOAM domain are to ensure that the addition of OAM information does not lead to fragmentation of the packet. Careful control of the MTU in a network is one of the reasons why IOAM is considered a domain specific feature, see also . In addition, the PMTU tolerance range in the IOAM domain should be identified (e.g. through configuration) and IOAM encapsulation operations and/or IOAM data field insertion (in case of incremental tracing) should not be performed if it exceeds the packet size beyond PMTU.
Packets with IOAM data or associated ICMP errors, should not arrive at destinations which have no knowledge of IOAM. Consider using IOAM in a transit network: Misleading ICMP errors due to addition and/or presence of OAM data in the packet can confuse a source of the packet that did not insert the OAM information.
OAM data leaks may affect the forwarding behavior and state of network elements outside an IOAM domain. Build a mechanism to prevent data leaks or be able to assure that upon leak network elements outside the domain are not affected i.e continue to process other valid packets.
Source OAM domain that inserted and leaked OAM data must be easy to identify for purpose of troubleshooting. For e.g. It very time consuming to troubleshoot source that inserted the EH but didn't remove when the packet traverses across AS (you have to walk the AS path, contacting each operator, asking them to verify their config, get packet captures etc.), and all the while you may have a number of angry customers/end-users.
Compliance with would require OAM data to be encapsulated instead of header/option insertion into inflight packets.

section.title: IOAM domains bounded by hosts
section.t: For deployments where the IOAM domain is bounded by hosts, hosts will perform the operation of IOAM data field encapsulation and decapsulation. IOAM data is carried in IPv6 packets as Hop-by-Hop or Destination options, see .

section.title: IOAM domains bounded by network devices
section.t: For deployments where the IOAM domain is bounded by network devices, network devices such as routers form the edge of an IOAM domain. Network devices will perform the operation of IOAM data field encapsulation and decapsulation.

section.title: Deployment options
section.t: This section lists out possible deployment options that can be employed to meet the requirements listed in section .

section.title: IPv6-in-IPv6 encapsulation
section.t:
Leverage an IPv6-in-IPv6 approach: Preserve the original IP packet and add an IPv6 header including IOAM data fields in an extension header in front of it, to forward traffic within and across the IOAM domain. The overlay network formed by the additional IPv6 header with the IOAM data fields included in an extension header is referred to as IOAM Overlay Network (ION) in this document. Perform an IPv6-in-IPv6 approach. The source address of the outer IPv6 header is that of the IOAM encapsulating node. The desitination address of the outer IPv6 header is the same as the inner IPv6 destination address, i.e. the destination address of the packet does not change.
To simplify debugging in case of leaked IOAM data fields in packets, consider a new IOAM E2E destination option to identify the Source IOAM domain (AS, v6 prefix). Insert this option into the IOAM destination options EH attached to the outer IPv6 header. This additional information would allow for easy identification of an AS operator that is the source of packets with leaked IOAM information.
All the IOAM options are defined with type "00 - skip over this option and continue processing the header. So presence of the options must not cause packet drop in the network elements that do not understand the option. In addition should be considered.

section.title: IP-in-IPv6 encapsulation with ULA
section.t: The "IP-in-IPv6 encapsulation with ULA" approach can be used to apply IOAM to an IPv6 as well as an IPv4 network. In addition, it fulfills requirement C4 (avoid leaks) by using ULA for the ION. Similar to the IPv6-in-IPv6 encapsulation approach above, the original IP packet is preserved. An IPv6 header including IOAM data fields in an extension header is added in front of it, to forward traffic within and across the IOAM domain. IPv6 addresses for the ION, i.e. the outer IPv6 addresses are assigned from the ULA space. Addressing and routing in the ION are to be configured so that the IP-in-IPv6 encapsulated packets follow the same path as the original, non-encapsulated packet would have taken.

section.title: Domain Interior Routes/Prefixes
section.t: For each IP route/prefix interior to the IOAM domain (i.e. hosts have addresses from these prefixes) a corresponding /128 route from the ION address space is allocated on every IOAM encapsulating/decapsulating router with the same metric and associated interface. When a host originated packet arrives at an IOAM encapsulating router, the destination address of the packet is looked up to find the corresponding /128 internal ION route. The encapsulating IOAM router imposes an IPv6 header on the packet and uses the retrieved /128 matching route as destination address. The IPv6 address of the encapsulating router is used as the source address. The encapsulating router also includes an IPv6 extension header to carry IOAM data fields, per . The original IP packet follows the new IPv6 extension header without any modification. This means that the ION route/prefix can be understood as an internal routeable index or proxy for the destination address/prefix of the original packet.

Based on the above configuration of prefixes on its interfaces, router X automatically generates and announces into the IGP (or BGP with no export community) matching ION internal /128s routes for each of them, using addresses from the ULA space mentioned above. This example uses fd1f:d2:feed::/48. The corresponding ION /128s for IOAM Router X's interfaces would be:

When a packet enters the IOAM domain at IOAM Router Z, with a destination address that falls within 2001:db8:0:1234::/64 (Router X's interface A prefix), the outer tunnel header's destination address would be the corresponding fd1f:d2:feed::1234/128 (Router X's intf A: ION /128 prefix). This encapsulated packet should follow the same path through the IOAM domain that a packet destined towards 2001:db8:0:1234::/64 should, from IOAM Router Z to IOAM Router X, because 2001:db8:0:1234::/64 and fd1f:d2:feed::1234/128 prefixes have both the same origin router and the same path metrics.

If another packet enters the IOAM domain at IOAM Router Z, with a destination address that falls within 2001:db8:0:4567::/64 (IOAM Router X intf C's second prefix), then the outer packet tunnel destination address would be the corresponding fd1f:d2:feed::4567/128 (Router X interface C's second and matching ION /128 prefix). As the metric for 2001:db8:0:4567::/64 and fd1f:d2:feed::4567/128 on Router X is 150, the path through the IOAM domain between IOAM Router Z and IOAM Router X for this packet could be different to the one taken in the previous example.

For completeness, for a different Router Y, with a destination address that falls within 2001:db8:0:3456::/64 (Router X intf C's first prefix), then the outer packet tunnel destination address would be the corresponding fd1f:d2:feed::3456/128 (Router X intf C's first and matching ION /128 prefix).

section.title: Domain Exterior Routes/Prefixes
section.t: For exterior routes, IPv6-in-IP tunnelling is used in a similar way. Transit across the ION follows the transit approach for traffic between BGP border routers, as described in RFC1772, "A.2.3 Encapsulation". In addition to the new IPv6 outer header, an IPv6 extension header carrying the IOAM data fields would be added.
